t: Song of Solomon 4
The Bridegroom Praises the Bride
The Beloved
Behold,*pn you are*i fair, my love! Behold,*ld you are*i fair! You*ld have*i dove’s eyes behind your veil. Your*ld hair is*i like a flock of goats, Going*ld down from Mount Gilead.
Your*ld teeth are*i like a flock of shorn sheep*i Which*ld have come up from the washing, Every*ld one of which bears twins, And*ld none is*i barren among them.
Your*ld lips are*i like a strand of scarlet, And*ld your mouth is lovely. Your*ld temples behind your veil Are*ild like a piece of pomegranate.
Your*ld neck is*i like the tower of David, Built*ld for an armory, On*ld which hang a thousand bucklers, All*ld shields of mighty men.
Your*ld two breasts are*i like two fawns, Twins*ld of a gazelle, Which*ld feed among the lilies.
Until*ln the day breaks And*ld the shadows flee away, I*ld will go my way to the mountain of myrrh And*ld to the hill of frankincense.
You*ln are*i all fair, my love, And*ld there*i is*i no spot in you.
Come*ld with me from Lebanon, my*i spouse, With*ld me from Lebanon. Look*ld from the top of Amana, From*ld the top of Senir and Hermon, From*ld the lions’ dens, From*ld the mountains of the leopards.
You*ln have ravished my heart, My*ld sister, my*i spouse; You*ld have ravished my heart With*ld one look*i of your eyes, With*ld one link of your necklace.
How*ld fair is your love, My*ld sister, my*i spouse! How*ld much better than wine is your love, And*ld the scent of your perfumes Than*ld all spices!
Your*ld lips, O my*i spouse, Drip*ld as the honeycomb; Honey*ld and milk are*i under your tongue; And*ld the fragrance of your garments Is*ild like the fragrance of Lebanon.
A*ln garden enclosed Is*ild my sister, my*i spouse, A*ld spring shut up, A*ld fountain sealed.
Your*ld plants are*i an orchard of pomegranates With*ld pleasant fruits, Fragrant*ld henna with spikenard,
Spikenard*ld and saffron, Calamus*ld and cinnamon, With*ld all trees of frankincense, Myrrh*ld and aloes, With*ld all the chief spices—
A*ld fountain of gardens, A*ld well of living waters, And*ld streams from Lebanon.
The Shulamite
Awake,*pn O north wind,*i And*ld come, O south! Blow*ld upon my garden, That*ild its spices may flow out. Let*ld my beloved come to his garden And*ld eat its pleasant fruits.
